Hi community, Hi Marq. I know this video I`m talking about is a 2 years old video, but is related to this video and many others of yours , where I have a completely different opinion and i strongly disagree with conclusion you got there. You said in the past " power user features, as much as we love`em, don`t sell phones" also you said " We figured this our many times when LG, Sony, Asus Zenphone try to bring in this features are not selling." My opinion is that features in this case are not a contributory factor to NOT selling the phones, nor the efforts to create something different. The problem is THE NAME of this brands, and is not even the brands fault, is the consumer. We live in a time where we are surrounded by consumerism, sheep effect, mass media control and all of that, and what I am trying to say with this is , if a big amount of people are buying Samsung and Iphone, because of the sheep effect (majority not thinking for themselves and not willing to be original and take their own choices/decisions in term of what represents them, they will just go for what the others do, which is Samsung and Iphone, and that is how in present that became the TREND , the majority. Basically all the other brands are surviving on minority which is day by day smaller, and like I said, majority of people are switching for Samsung / Iphone, but the same people don't have a clue why they buy this brands/phones. They just do because the next door did the same, and so on. Are a lot of brands and phones out there, which may fulfil the needs of a lot of people, better than samsung / iphone for the price. People which need stronger battery and good camera good overall specs, but for less money, which obviously Iphone cant offer. People which need better camera but they would like something more unique in the same time and not that pricy , which obviously Samsung cant offer, but the other brands you mentioned are slowly dying, because of lack of originality. Again, majority will chose to get  Iphone or Samsung regardless, only because of thinking " what if my work colleague see I bought an Oneplus, some people dont even know Oneplus makes phones, they all have iphones" , and etc. That is the real reason why this brands are dying, because majority become day by day fake, trend, sheep controlled.  I hope this make sense as english is not my first language. Take care, have a good day !

Been using a xiaomi for the past 4 years, before my current phone which is a pixel. I hate the xiaomi stock UI so much and there's so much bloatware garbage installed by default, but other than that I think it's really raised my standards for what a phone should be able to do. The phone is still working absolutely fine 4 years on, the only sign of age is the battery depletes extremely fast in cold weather (or at least says it does, I know it's a common thing for phones to misrepresent the battery remaining when it's cold just by how they work normally) but in comfortable temperatures it's still faster and lasts longer than my pixel. The rest of the hardware is great too, plastic back but I'll always have a case on it. Still has an aux port and expandable storage too. Camera doesn't hold a candle to the pixel but still far far outclasses the Motorola I used before the xiaomi and is generally good enough for everything I want it to do. Oh and this wasn't even their flagship model, this was all in a low-mid range model that cost the same new as the refurbished 2 gen old pro model pixel I got. Oh and as a bonus, the charger that came with it for free is better than the official pixel charger which you have to buy separately.

Perhaps the back screen can be useful to consume less battery if you just want to see a limited amount of info, for example a timer or the clock or a notification or two.  Just trying to think about why I would prefer to use the small one instead of the front screen... not sure how much battery life that could save.  Using the main cameras for selfies I think is a huge one because I have frequently wanted to use the better rear camera which has better wide angle on my Pixel but can't since I can't see myself :)

Assumption: the primary 6-ishâ€³ LTPO AMOLED is the main power sink (more pixels, higher peak brightness, higher touch/refresh ceilings). In that case, offloading â€œquick tasksâ€ to the rear display makes sense: fewer active pixels and lower nits generally mean less panel power. For gaming it depends: you only get real savings if the game actually renders at the rear displayâ€™s native resolution/refresh. If itâ€™s a straight mirror of the main UI, the GPU/SoC workload (fill rate, compositing) is similar, so battery benefit will be limited. Practical use-cases where the back screen should shine: camera preview/shutter, turn-by-turn glances, music/podcast controls, authenticator codes, payments, and always-on widgets. Curious if Xiaomi exposes per-app targeting for the rear panel on the 17 Pro.

The specs are all fake. The battery is actually ~3500 mAh. Chip is Mediatek 520. Display is 45 Hz. Back display only works for 30 days. Front screen has a reflection issue. Breaks if dropped from just 3rd floor. Overall, the Apple sucks. I would rather buy Xiaomi 17.

I'm a little surprised, Marques, that you fall into the "Android spec" superiority as an advantage. Yes, iPhone 17 Pro Max has "only" 5000mah battery while the Xiaomi Pro Max has 7500! A whopping 50% improvement. Only real world tests show that they perform on par - i.e. they both maintain the same amount of battery over the same amount of effort - simply because iPhone is FAR more efficient - A19 is more efficient than snapdragon elite, and overall the iOS optimization is. Should I continue? The new snapdragon may finally have benchmarks that are keeping up with Apple, but the actual performance you would get in an android ecosystem will be somewhat lower (albeit still fast enough - all new chips are fast enough :)). Cameras may be 50mp vs 48mp (who cares) but are they really better? iPhone 17 pro max scored the highest DxO score outside of the "scary" camera-unbalanaced phones (the pura 80 and the oppo x8, though the latter is only a point better).   Bottom line - this tells the whole story - an Android needs a MUCH better spec list, to offer similar performance to an iPhone, and even then it's still an Android.... the Xiaomi 17 Pro Max seems like a totally great Android phone, if you don't mind the chinese connection, but to call it better than iPhone 17 Pro Max?   PFFT.

None of the features exclusive to IOS that their users want are on this device. So why would this phone sell well in the US? Whatâ€™s the threat here? Itâ€™s basically just another android phone.   If anything, this is a device that other android manufacturers in the US should be afraid of. Itâ€™s more likely to snag a substantial amount of Android market share than iPhone users. Isnâ€™t it obvious?   iMessage? FaceTime? Airdrop? iCloud? Eco-system devices like Apple Watch, AirPods, etc. iPhone users simply donâ€™t care about specs and thatâ€™s a fact. This device is no threat to Apple. Itâ€™s definitely more of a threat to other Android makers for sure, but you canâ€™t replicate the iPhone experience. You can argue all you want and you can match their specs, but ultimately thatâ€™s not why people purchase the iPhone. What they want, others donâ€™t have. Plain and simple.

Itâ€™s great to see comparison videos like this, but as someone who switched from 20 years of Samsung to Xiaomi earlier this year, I can say with experience the long-term experience isnâ€™t quite as good as itâ€™s made out to be.  I bought the Xiaomi Mix Flip in January in Hong Kong after feeling a bit disillusioned by Samsungâ€™s lack of innovation lately. The sales staff told me it came with a global warranty (including the UK), which helped seal the deal. They also mentioned that the inner display had a screen protector, while the outer display was tough enough not to need one.  Four months later, the outer screen cracked after a short drop â€” indoors, while I was sitting down, and with a case on.  When I contacted the UK team, they initially denied having any warranty at all. Only after I sent a screenshot from Xiaomiâ€™s official site did they acknowledge it â€” though of course, since the damage was accidental, it wasnâ€™t covered.  Now that Iâ€™m back in Hong Kong, I went to their office in person just to share my experience. The staff were fairly dismissive â€” they told me to buy a protector elsewhere (since thereâ€™s no official one) and said, essentially, that â€œthese things happen.â€ They did offer to fix it, for a charge, but it feels misleading that they donâ€™t sell outer screen protectors while their sales staff emphasize the screenâ€™s toughness and offer no meaningful warranty on it.  Another major reason I chose this phone was the Leica camera, since photography is part of my work. Unfortunately, the camera frequently overheats and shuts down after about 15 minutes of use. The customer service rep told me this was â€œnormal.â€  Itâ€™s disappointing to see a brand that positions itself as innovative yet lacks the support and reliability expected from a premium experience. I just wanted to share this perspective, since these longer-term realities often donâ€™t come through in quick online reviews.

However, I can recognize the good use of this rear screen and I think there's not much discussion about how useful/advantageous it will be for doing IRL (in real life) live streams on social media platforms in general (TikTok, Instagram, etc.). This is because it combines the quality of a rear camera recording with the ability of the person streaming to see themselves and react to the chat simultaneously. And no other smartphone can offer this combination.  Therefore, those who are calling this rear screen useless, in my opinion, are simply failing to visualize broader situations where it is truly very useful. Because it's undeniable that this type of live stream has become increasingly popular among social media users, And this phone is set to be the best by far for this type of content production.

Fun fact... Single core score means literally nothing in practice. It's like horsepower per cylinder, in a gas engine, which hey cool it's a number, but does any engine have only 1 cylinder? Nope. There is also no task that can use only 1 core, but is also somehow not intensive enough to need any more than 1 core to complete.

Silicon carbon batteries also degrade faster (so will the battery life hold up in 1-3 years?).  50W wireless charging? With what charger? Won't it thermally throttle (Many phones thermally throttle with just 15-25W)? Similarly with 100W wired charging, via PPS? How long does it actually maintain 100W?

Xiaomi could have been the best but they have so many software issues it is ridiculous. I had the Xiaomi 15 Ultra for almost 4 months and even the most basic features had issues.  Playback in the background would automatically pause all of the time. I tested this with multiple devices and the issue persisted.  Apps can have wrong scaling and will display things like the on screen keyboard outside the borders of the display so it was impossible to log in to some apps.  There is a bug in the os that thinks you have typed in the wrong password to the wifi network you use even though you are logged in and it works. I tested this on 3 different networks and the issue is always present.  This means the phone sends notifications several times every hour for as long as it is logged in to wifi.  Some apps would crash everytime the phone tried to autofill my information so I had to manually fill in all my info when logging in.  I had the official Photography kit that Xiaomi sells and the phone would refuse to charge via the usb c port on the kit so both had to be charged separately.  I tested this with 3 different charging stations I have which support almost every protocol and with the official and third party cables and only one third part cable managed to charge it if I changed the charging station to low current mode.  It was the Anker 250W gan station that managed to charge both at the same time.  I changed to the iPhone 17 Pro and I do not experience any of these issues anymore.  The good thing about Xiaomi is all of these issues are software related and not hardware defects so they can be fixed but I do not have big hopes for that. Many of these features have been considered basic features by other manufacturers for a decade at this point in time.

The interesting thing is despite the available of phones like these and Oppo and others in China, the I Phone 17 line still has very strong demand in China and is doing extremely well there in sales. So for those saying if these phones were available in the US, I phone would be done, itâ€™s not necessarily accurate.   I think despite Xiaomiâ€™s attempts to both emulate and outdo the IPhone in specs, there are certain things that cannot be so easily duplicated. Outside the obvious global brand recognition of Apple for being an early innovator in the smartphone world in general, there are other factors to consider.   One is the video quality. While no longer the absolute photography king, Iphones still reign supreme in video quality and is the favored tool of the majority of mobile creators on a global level, which is what many people, myself included, often purchase it for, is for its innovation in professional video features moreso than iterative spec bumps. One is hard pressed to find a mobile video creator anywhere who doesnâ€™t have at least one IPhone. And while no longer the photo king, I phones are still in the royal family of mobile photograph while being king in videography.   And also the fact for content creators or heavy social media users, I phone photos and video are optimized for many of the biggest social media sites in the world, meaning that while the specs may not seem as impressive on paper, the photos and video actually look better on those sites than higher spec phones.   And second (possibly first) the ecosystem is still unparalleled and massively convenient. I literally take a photo or video with my phone and it automatically goes to my back up phone and my iPad and my Mac without my doing anything extra.   In the end, just because something isnâ€™t a â€œcheapâ€ knockoff and in someways improves upon the original formula doesnâ€™t mean it is still not recognizable to many people as a knockoff.   Moreso than spec bumps, I like phenomenal all rounders. I like phenomenal video and photography and optimization and security. Moreso than hundreds of features I never use, I like some thing that focuses on the key features that are most important to me as an individual user.   I like seeing android phones continue to innovate, and my first phones were Note-line and S-series Samsungs and I still like them better in terms of multitude of features and customizations etc. But when it comes to â€œprofessional use,â€ resale value, long term endurance, and straight reliability and ecosystem and security and no-nonsense performance, I reach more for my IPhone.

The battery of the Xiaomi 17 Pro Max lasts about the same  as the iPhone 17 Pro Max under heavy use, even though the Xiaomi has 2500 mAh more. Many times, specs on their own are useless if you donâ€™t take into account how each component interacts with the rest of the phone. A phone with a 3000 mAh battery and good CPU optimization can last longer than one with a larger battery but poorer CPU optimization. Sometimes, comparing only the numbers can be a bit misleading; for example, a 200 MP camera can be overall worse than a 24 MP one.  That said, the Xiaomi 17 Pro Max is amazing. I hope this pushes Apple to step up its game and bring us some real innovation in the coming years, beyond things like finally adding a calculator app to the iPad...

Recently, Antutu noticed that some users are comparing the scores of Antutu iOS version with the scores of Antutu Android version, which we think is unfair comparison.  First of all, since there are obvious differences in the kernel and the development language used by the iOS system and the Android system, the iOS version and the Android version of Antutu Benchmark are two different softwares and the test methods for the two versions are significantly different.  Second, Antutu iOS version and Antutu Android version use different APIs when running the GPU test. The iOS version uses Appleâ€™s Metal API while the Android version uses OpenGL ES and vulkan API. Although the test scenarios used in the two versions are the same, the rendering mechanisms are different, neither does the stress requirement for the hardware.  All in all, the scoring mechanisms for the iOS version and the Android version of Antutu Benchmark are significantly different, and therefore the test results of the two versions are not directly comparable.  To put it simply, the test results of Antutu benchmark only support the comparison within the same system based on the same major version and not support cross-version or cross-platform comparison.  Thatâ€™s said by Antutu Developers.

Apple holds tons of design patents and utility patents in the U.S. â€” covering things like the shape of the camera module, the layout of the buttons, and even UI features. If Xiaomi sold a phone here that looked almost identical to an iPhone, Apple could hit them with major lawsuits. In China and some other regions, Apple doesnâ€™t have as strong a legal grip on these patents, so Xiaomi (and other brands) can push designs closer to Appleâ€™s without big consequences. U.S. carrier & regulatory barriers For any phone to be sold officially in the U.S., it has to pass through FCC certification and work on U.S. carrier bands (Verizon, AT&T, T-Mobile, etc.). Xiaomi doesnâ€™t bother going through this expensive, complicated process because the U.S. isnâ€™t a main market for them.

A new EU law requires smartphone and tablet manufacturers to provide software and security updates for their products for five years after they have withdrawn a smartphone or tablet from the market. Realistically, this means at least 6 to 7 years of updates. This law applies to all phones and tablets launched since June 2025. The update policy may change internationally, as these updates have to be made available anyway...apart from the positive consequences for marketing. This law was specifically created to counteract the weak update support of Chinese devices and to increase the lifespan of technical devices.

All of that is surface-wise though, once one really looks into it things aren't so great as they appear to be. Software differences between the Chinese version of HyperOS (but it happened with MIUI just the same) and the international one are abysmal; and it's been like that for at least a decade already!! I have experienced both and it's night and day, there is plenty of stuff announced on new updates for OS that doesn't make it to the international version; they have different stores, different themes selections, etc.  Stock apps, all filled with "recommendations" (read, ads) in the international version of the OS; off the top of my head: the Downloads app, Music, Video (and this one is insane! One can only disable ads temporarily for up to a month, then they get re-enabled!), the browser, the themes app, ...  Never ending selection of sponsored apps pre-installed with the phone, inability to disable some of the apps unless through ADB (I am not even asking to uninstall them, disabling is fine). Really, pretty good hardware (depending on the model), software not up to par. Firmware upgrades are market dependent, if you're lucky to be in a large region and your model is popular, you may get more or less regular updates for a while, otherwise updates may stop flowing maybe even half a year before they're declared EOL (declared, but clearly they were already). My only hope is that things change now with the EU mandating some things to happen and pushing vendors for longer support windows.  Obviously anything remotely related to custom builds is out of the question. To think that Xiaomi had such a large following of tech people and look at what they've become ğŸ˜” They even wanted Google to implement something to prevent users from extracting the APKs out of the phone back in 2022, just the installer mind you, nothing hidden or esoteric; luckily it went nowhere.
The question is, will there be a global version?

Most people would say Xiaomi in less than a second but let's not forget that Xiaomi announced its 17 pro just one week after the iPhone, with a fully functional model, it was complete, ready to ship, something that we all know it's impossible to do in the tech field, you can't just design, order the pieces with your suppliers chain and build a copy ready to sell and ship in just a week. So the real question here is: which project came first: apple's or xiaomi's, and that we probably will never know for sure but I'd guess Xiaomi's project came first due its complexity and suppliers chain but they are okay with letting Apple announcing it first because they wanted all the buzz and marketing after it.
